questions.question_text: A 42 Y/o woman presents with a history of irregular vaginal bleeding and postcoital spotting. She has not had a Pap smear in over five years. On physical examination, the cervix appears abnormal, and a biopsy confirms cervical carcinoma. Which of the following is the most common histological type of cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option B)

Adenocarcinoma (Option A)

Most common histological type of cervical cancer.

2nd most common histological type of cervical cancer.

Commonly arises from transformation zone

Commonly arises from endocervical mucus producing columnar cells.

Further divided into three types:

  • Keratinizing
  • Nonkeratinizing
  • Papillary

Further divided into:

  • Mucinous (most common subtype)
  • Endometrioid
  • Serous
  • Clear cell
  • Mesonephric.

Histology: Nests of malignant squamous cells with brisk lymphocytic response and keratin pearls at center.

 

Histology: Columnar, relatively mucin poor cells with stratified atypical nuclei and brisk mitotic activity. Chronic inflammation may be present (asterisk)

questions.question_text: A 25 y/o female presents for her annual examination. Her Pap smear results show atypical squamous cells, and cannot rule out high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (ASC-H). What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Bethesda Classification

Inference

Management

Negative for Intraepithelial Lesion or Malignancy (NILM)

Normal smear
  • Aged 21-29 - Cytology every 3 years
  • Aged 30-65- Cytology every 3 years or co-testing every 5 years

Atypical Squamous Cells of Undetermined Significance (ASC-US)

Abnormal squamous cells but do not meet the criteria for a squamous intraepithelial lesion
  • Followed by HPV co-test
  • If Positive HPV: Colposcopy.
  • If Negative HPV: Repeat co-test after 3 years.
  • If HPV Testing NOT done: Repeat cytology in 1 year; colposcopy if abnormal

Atypical Squamous Cells (ASC-H)

Indicates a higher risk of precancerous or cancerous cells and necessitates further investigation to rule out more serious conditions.
  • Colposcopy with biopsy. (Option B)
  • HPV testing may be considered in conjunction with the colposcopy.

LSIL

Mildly abnormal cells, changes attributable to HPV

Women ≥25 Years

  • Colposcopy.
  • If HPV-negative: Repeat cotesting in 1 year.

Women 21–24 Years

  • Repeat cytology at 12 and 24 months (follow ASC-US guidelines).

Pregnant Women

  • Manage as non-pregnant.
  • No ECC; defer colposcopy until 6 weeks postpartum if needed.

Postmenopausal Women

  • Reflex HPV, repeat Pap (6 & 12 months), or colposcopy.
  • If HPV-negative/no CIN: Repeat in 12 months.
  • If HPV-positive/ASC or worse: Colposcopy.
  • Routine screening after 2 negative cytology results.

High-grade Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion (HSIL)

Suggests a high-grade precancerous lesion.

Colposcopy with biopsy.

Adenocarcinoma In Situ (AIS)

Indicates the presence of precancerous glandular cells.

Colposcopy with biopsy.

Malignant Cells

Indicates the presence of cancerous cells.
  • Colposcopy with biopsy.
  • Endocervical curettage is avoided during pregnancy to prevent uterine irritation, bleeding, or potential harm to the developing fetus.
  • If colposcopy-directed biopsy fails to confirm a malignancy, diagnostic conization is done.

Which type of transformation zone is observed in this woman?

Type

Seen in

Appearance

Type 1 (Option A)
  • Adolescence
  • Pregnancy 
  • OCPs

The entire TZ is visible and is only ectocervical

questions.question_text: A 45-year-old woman has presented with abdominal distension and discomfort for the past few months. On examination, there is bilateral pelvic tenderness with a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound confirms a large cystic lesion 8-10 cm in the right ovary with irregular solid areas. Serum CA-125 levels are elevated. Which of the following epithelial ovarian tumors is most likely to present with the described clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.
 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma (Option A): Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.
 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors

Endometrioid Carcinoma (Option C): Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor (Option D): Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

Ovarian Tumor

Epithelial

Sex cord-stromal

Germ cell

  • Mucinous
  • Endometroid

  • Brenner
  • Granulosa cell
  • Thecoma
  • Fibroma
  • Sertoli - Leydig

  • Embryonal carcinoma

Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is most appropriate as the first-line adjuvant treatment for this patient following her surgery?

options.A: Malignant ovarian tumors require surgery immediately after pregnancy
options.B: Benign ovarian tumors are removed preferably in the first trimester
options.C: Corpus luteum cyst must be operated before the 12th week of gestation

questions.question_text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman, non-obese, presents with complaints of irregular vaginal bleeding over the past two months. She reports no significant medical history except for using unopposed estrogen hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the last five years Which condition, characterized by elevated estrogen levels alone, increases her risk of developing endometrial cancer?
questions.explanation:
Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • Lynch syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNS-IUS

questions.question_text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of breast development and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals a mixed solid and cystic ovarian mass measuring 5 cm. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of inhibin B and estradiol. The HPE slide is given below:- What is the next step in the management of the patient?

options.A: Observation and follow-up with repeat ultrasound
options.B: Hormonal therapy to manage precocious puberty
options.D: Chemotherapy to reduce the size of the tumor

questions.explanation:
A. Granulosa Cell Tumors

Incidence

  • 70% of all ovarian SCSTs are granulosa cell tumors

  • 2% of all ovarian neoplasms

Types

  • Adult form (95%)

  • Juvenile form (5%)

Characteristics

  • Slow growing

  • Solid or cystic or mixed

  • Cut section shows yellow/orange due to lipid content

HPE Appearance

  • Round/polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm

  • Coffee bean nuclei

  • Call-Exner bodies (Pathognomonic)

 

Hormonal Activity & Markers

  • Secrete inhibin B, estrogen, and AMH

Clinical Features

  • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty

  • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding

  • Postmenopausal: Bleeding often with endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma

Prognosis

  • Good overall prognosis

  • 5-year survival rate for stage I disease is about 95%

B. Theca Cell Tumors

Presentation

Presents after Menopause

Characteristics

Solid yellow tumor containing lipoid material

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Estrogen

Clinical Features

Estrogenic (causes post-menopausal bleed)

Usually Benign

C. Sertoli Leydig Tumors / Arrhenoblastomas

Incidence

0.5% of all ovarian tumours, 5% of all SCST’s

Characteristics

Small, solid, unilateral tumor and on HPE Reinke crystals are pathognomonic.

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Androgens, Inhibin, AFP

Clinical Features

  • Hirsutism (Male pattern baldness, excessive hair growth) - Reversible

  • Virilization (Hoarseness, Breast atrophy, Clitoromegaly) - Permanent

  • Oligomenorrhea to Amenorrhea

questions.question_text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a large adnexal mass detected on a routine pelvic examination. She complains of intermittent pelvic pain and bloating over the past few months. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 10 cm complex ovarian mass diagnosed as germ cell tumor. What is the most appropriate surgical approach in this scenario?

options.B: Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with staging and preservation of the contralateral ovary and uterus
options.C: Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with omentectomy and lymph node dissection
options.D: Laparoscopic cystectomy to remove only the cystic portion of the mass

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about HE4 and the Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm (ROMA) score is correct?

options.A: HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.
options.B: The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.
options.C: HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women.
options.D: The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer.

questions.explanation:
Pre-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 12 + 2.38 x LN(HE4) + 0.0626 x LN (CA-125)

Post-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 8.09 + 1.04 x LN(HE4) + 0.732 x LN (CA-125)

ROMA(%): 100 X Exp PI/ (1 + Exp PI)

ROMAcut-off: 7.4% for premenopausal women

25.3% postmenopausal women

Which of the following factors is most commonly associated with the development of ovarian epithelial surface tumors?

options.C: High parity and use of oral contraceptives
options.D: Familial history of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations

Protective factors for ovarian cancer

Age between 45 and 60 years

Physical exercise

Nulliparous or of low parity (higher estrogen exposure)

Related to ovulation-anovulation (multiparity, OCP, breastfeeding) (Option C)

Women with previous PCOS, or on Tamoxifen (higher estrogen exposure)

Surgeries- hysterectomy, tubal ligation, salpingectomy

High-calorie, High-fat diet (Higher estrogen exposure)

  

Genetic predisposition BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 gene mutation (Option D)

Late menopause and early menarche (high estrogen exposure)

Family history of breast and Gastrointestinal cancer

Multiple cycles of ovulation induction

Scars

↑ Scars → Epithelium→ Overhealing → Epithelial ovarian CA

Further evaluation shows that the tumor predominantly comprises glands with irregular architecture, cytologic atypia, and mitotic activity. What histopathological type of endometrial cancer does this description most likely correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Endometrioid Carcinoma

Serous carcinoma

Clear cell carcinoma

HPE Image

Features
  • Tubular glands with back to back pattern
  • Eosinophilic keratin deposition
  • May demonstrate cytological atypia (Option A)
  • Complex papillae
  • Free cells with significant cytological atypia
  • (Option B)
  • Hobnail cells with clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Nuclear Atypia seen
  • (Option C)

  • Poorer
  • Poorer

questions.question_text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a non-healing lesion on her vulva. On PE, a thickened, whitish plaque and ulceration are noted on the labia majora. Histopathology reveals atypical squamous cells confined to the epithelium with marked basal atypia and abnormal keratinisation as shown below. Which of the following is the patient suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Normal vulva

  • Lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Vulvar LSIL
  • Seen in younger women (option B)
  • Etiology: HPV effect
  • Flat lesions with condyloma
  • Self limited, not precancerous

Histology:

 

 

  • Mild atypical cells in the lower third of epithelium
  • Koilocytes in the upper layer

Vulval HSIL
  • Formerly called usual VIN (option A&C)
  • Seen in younger women
  • Etiology: HPV infection, STDs, immunosuppression, smoking
  • Multicentric & multifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Atypical squamous cells in all layers of epithelium
  • Extensive parakeratosis
  • Koilocytic changes in the upper layer.

Differentiated VIN
  • Seen in older, postmenopausal women (option D)
  • Etiology: Lichen sclerosus and other chronic dermatological conditions
  • Unicentric and unifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Prominent nucleoli
  • Basal atypia with acanthosis, dyskeratosis

Vulvar LSIL
  • Self-limited condition.
  • Not treated unless symptomatic.

Vulvar HSIL and differentiated VIN
  • Precancerous conditions.
  • All lesions should be treated.
  • Treatment options:
  • Wide local excision
  • Laser ablation
  • Topical 5-FU or imiquimod

questions.question_text: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with SCC arising from the Bartholin gland following a biopsy after she presented with complaints of unilateral swelling in the vulvar area. Which of the following is an indication for bartholin gland biopsy?

options.C: Solid mass arising from Bartholin gland

questions.explanation:
Bartholin gland carcinoma
  • Maybe adenocarcinomas, SCC, or transitional cell carcinoma

Clinical features
  • Painless vulval mass
  • Perineal pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Spreads to ischiorectal fossa and pelvic nodes

Investigations
  • MRI
  • Bartholin biopsy: Indications include,
    • Woman over 40 years
    • Recurrent cyst/abscess
    • All solid masses

Treatment
  • Radical vulvectomy + Ipsilateral/bilateral groin dissection
  • Pre/post-operative chemoradiation

questions.question_text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, mobile lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 mm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A)

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B)

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C)

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D)

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

Classification

  • Vulvar HSIL (formerly called Usual VIN): Multicentric and multifocal disease
  • Differentiated VIN: Precursor to most vulvar SCC

Clinical features

  • Non-specific symptoms like pruritus, burning and pain are seen in some patients.

HSIL= high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; LSIL= low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

Specific Condition

Treatment



 

Ovarian androgens

Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Oral contraceptive pills

  • Metformin
  • Lifestyle changes

  • Assisted reproductive technology

Luteoma of pregnancy/theca lutein cysts

Conservative management.
 

Adrenal androgens

Androgen-producing tumour

Remove the tumor.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (late onset) 21-hydroxylase deficiency

Glucocorticoid replacement and suppression.

Varies as to cause.

Exogenous androgens

Hormonal drugs

Withdraw the offending drug.

Excessive conversion of DHT in hair follicle
  • Spironolactone

questions.question_text: In a patient with galactorrhea, which serum prolactin level range is most commonly associated with prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas?

A 28-year-old woman with irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and infertility has a serum prolactin level of 95 ng/mL and a 6 mm pituitary microadenoma. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological treatment?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Description

Bromocriptine

  • It is suitable for patients trying to conceive, those with psychiatric disorders (lower risk of impulse control issues), and patients with Parkinson's disease (provides symptomatic relief).
  • It is cost-effective compared to cabergoline and typically requires daily dosing.

Cabergoline
  • It is preferred for larger prolactinomas, cases resistant to bromocriptine, and patients intolerant to bromocriptine.
  • It achieves rapid tumour shrinkage, offers better tolerability, and is more effective in normalising prolactin levels with less frequent dosing (typically twice weekly).

questions.question_text: Match the following condition with its appropriate diagrammatic representation. Disorder Figure A.Accreta 1. B.Percreta 2. C.Increta 3.
questions.explanation:
Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the endometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta
  • Remove as much placenta as possible.
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding.

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy.
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics.
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy.

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions is the most common developmental anomaly of the placenta?
questions.explanation:
• Multiparity
  • Maternal age more than 40 years
  • Asian race
  • Presence of uterine scar
  • Prior curettage
  • Prior placenta previa
  • Multiple pregnancies

Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

(Option A)

 
  • Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.
  • It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

 

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

(Option C)

 
  • Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.
  • The spectrum has 3 conditions:
    • Accreta
    • Increta
    • Percreta
  • It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta (Option D)

 

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

 

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits and associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

Battledore Placenta

 
  • An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the center.
  • It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labor and fetal distress.
Placenta spuria
  • Unequal placenta not connected by vessel
  • Succenturiate placenta
  • Placenta accreta spectrum
  • Ring-shaped Placenta
  • Placenta membranacea
  • Bilobed Placenta
  • Circummarginate Placenta
  • Battledore Placenta

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old G2P1 pregnant woman undergoes an ultrasound showing a single umbilical artery. Which of the following is associated with the given finding?
Match the following images to the specific insertion of the umbilical cord: Image Diagnosis a) Fucrate insertion 2. b) Eccentric insertion 3. c) Velamentous insertion 4. d) Marginal insertion
questions.explanation:
Types of abnormal cord insertion

Properties
  1. Marginal insertion

 
  • Marginal cord insertion occurs when the umbilical cord is within 2cm or less from the edge of the placenta.
  • Also known as battledore placenta.
  • Occurs in about 6% of singleton gestations and 11% of twin pregnancies.
  • It rarely causes problems but may result in the cord being pulled off during placenta delivery.
  • In monochorionic twins, it may be associated with weight discordance.

2. Eccentric insertion

 
  • Eccentric insertion occurs when a lateral insertion is >2 cm from the placental edge.
  • This variant of umbilical cord insertion generally poses no identifiable fetal risk.

3. Velamentous insertion:

 
  • This condition is characterised by umbilical vessels travelling within the membranes before reaching the placental margin.
  • Incidence of approximately 1% in singleton pregnancies and 6% in twin pregnancies.
  • Can be diagnosed antenatally via ultrasound.
  • The presence of a velamentous Cord at the level of internal Os is known as VASA PREVIA.
  • It can cause fetal bleeding and death during delivery.

4. Fucrate insertion

 
  • Umbilical vessels lose their protective Wharton jelly shortly before insertion.
  • They are covered only by an amnion sheath, making them prone to compression, twisting, and thrombosis.

questions.question_text: Which is the most common variety of abruptio placenta?
questions.explanation:
Revealed
  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed
  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed
  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0

1

Fetal heart sounds are normal

Cause

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old male presents with infertility. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infertility?

2. Testicular (peripheral): Intrinsic disorders (High FSH and LH)

    • Klinefelter syndrome (Most common) (Option B)
    • Immotile cilia (Kartagener) syndrome
  • Varicocele: Most common reversible cause (Option A)

  • Testicular torsion
  • Mumps orchitis
  • Heat exposure: Miners
  • Toxins: smoking, radiation, drug abuse

3. Post-testicular: (Normal LH and FSH)

A 38-year-old obese woman presents with heavy and prolonged vaginal bleeding for the past six months, lasting more than 10 days. Which of the following could NOT be a possible cause of bleeding according to the PALM-COEIN classification?

The male partner should be treated along with the female partner in which of the following conditions? i) Candidiasis ii) Bacterial vaginosis iii) Trichomoniasis iv) Gonorrhoea v) Chlamydia vi) Chancroid
questions.explanation:
Condition

Male Partner Treatment

Candidiasis
  • Male partners need not be treated except when symptomatic.
  • Use nystatin ointment locally for a few days after each instance of coitus.
  • Condom use is preferred during treatment.

Trichomoniasis
  • Follow the same treatment as the female partner:
    • Metronidazole 500 mg BD for 1 week, or a single 2 g dose.
    • Tinidazole 2 g single dose is also effective.
  • Use a condom during coitus until the female partner is cured.

Gonorrhoea
  • Cover gonorrhea, syphilis, and chlamydia.
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM + Azithromycin 1 g PO once, or Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 7 days.
  • Use a condom until both partners are disease-free.

Chlamydia
  • It should be treated with the same regimen as the female partner to reduce resistance or recurrence.
  • Azithromycin 1 g once, or Doxycycline 100 mg BID for 7 days.
  • Abstain from sex until both partners are treated and asymptomatic.

Chancroid
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose, or Erythromycin 500 mg PO every 8 hours for 7 days.
  • Longer treatment for HIV-positive patients.

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with an intense burning sensation and thick vaginal discharge. She reports no foul odour with erythema on pelvic examination. A wet mount preparation is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causative organism
  • Candida albicans (Dimorphic fungi)
    • Blastospores: Transmission and colonisation
    • Mycelia: Tissue invasion & adherence

Symptoms
  • Pruritus, burning, and splash dysuria
  • Erythema and oedema on pelvic examination

Diagnosis
  • Curdy white discharge resembles cottage cheese
  • Vaginal wall plaque: petechiae when removed
  • Microscopy on KOH preparation: budding yeast and pseudohyphae (image).
  • Culture: Bismuth Glycine Glucose Yeast agar (BiGGYagar) or Nickerson agar (selective for candidiasis).

Types
  1. Uncomplicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompetant women
    2. Good prognosis
    3. Causative organism: C. albicans
  2. Complicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompromised women: DM, TB, pregnancy and chemotherapy patients
    2. Recurrent and difficult-to-treat.
    3. Causative organism: Non albican species like C. tropicalis, glabrata

questions.question_text: A 27-year-old female presents with a yellow vaginal discharge and itching. A pelvic examination revealed an erythematous cervix. A wet mount preparation is shown below. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

options.A: It is the most common cause of non-viral sexually transmitted diseases worldwide.
options.B: The preferred treatment is a single dose of metronidazole.
options.C: Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.
options.D: Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

questions.explanation:
Causative organism
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (anaerobic flagellate protozoan).

Clinical findings
  • Severe irritation and pruritus.
  • Foul, thin, greenish-yellow, frothy discharge.
  • Dysuria, dyspareunia, vulvar pruritus, and lower abdominal pain.

Diagnosis
  • Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Microscopy: motile trichomonads.
  • Colpitis macularis (strawberry vagina): subepithelial haemorrhage on cervix/vagina.
  • Lab-based NAATs for trichomonal DNA: (Option C)
    • Repeat test if suspect persisted infection/ re-infection.
    • Not distinguishing live from dead (adequately treated) trichomonas; hence, repeat testing delayed for 3 weeks.

Risk factor
  • Increase incidence with age.

Treatment
  • DOC: Metronidazole 500 mg (400 mg) BD for 7 days or 2 g orally once (Option B).
  • If allergy: desensitisation.
  • Treat sex partners (Option D).
  • Abstain sex and condom use.

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old female presents with severe lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent vaginal discharge. She has bilateral adnexal and cervical motion tenderness on examination. Investigations show elevated WBC, positive swabs for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis, and bilateral tubo-ovarian abscesses on ultrasound. She is admitted to the ward. options.D: Oral Levofloxacin 500 mg OD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD

questions.explanation:
In-patient antibiotic therapy

Parenteral regimen A

Cefoxitin 2 g IV every 6 hours for 7 days + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days

Parenteral regimen B

Clindamycin 900 mg IV every 8 hours + Gentamicin 2 mg/kg IV (loading dose), followed by 1.5 mg/kg IV (maintenance dose) every 8 hours

• Aztreonam (2 g IV slowly) is similar to aminoglycoside and can be used. It has no renal toxicity, but is more expensive.

Alternative parenteral regimen

Ampicillin-sulbactam 3 g IV every 6 hours 3-5 days + Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID for 14 days

questions.question_text: A 24-year-old sexually active woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain, fever, and unusual vaginal discharge. She is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. What is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?

options.A: Azithromycin 1 g PO OD + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
options.B: Cefixime 400 mg PO single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
options.C: Levofloxacin 500 mg PO OD X 14 days, and Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
options.D: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg/125 mg PO BD X 14 days, and Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days

questions.explanation:
Out-patient antibiotic therapy

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose or

Cefoxitin, 2g IM single dose and probenecid, 1 g PO single dose or

Injection Cefotaxime IV

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO, BD for 14 days with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days

Option A
  • Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Azithromycin does not cover other pathogens, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • Metronidazole targets anaerobic organisms, but this combination lacks coverage for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, making it suboptimal.

Option C
  • Levofloxacin is effective against organisms causing PID, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • However, it is generally reserved as an alternative therapy when other first-line antibiotics cannot be used.
  • While Levofloxacin could be used as a first-line therapy, it is not recommended due to antibiotic resistance as it is used as a second line treatment for tuberculosis

Option D
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate is broad-spectrum and effective against many bacterial infections.
    • It does not adequately cover Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Doxycycline covers Chlamydia trachomatis but not the polymicrobial nature of PID.
  • Therefore, this combination is suboptimal for treating PID according to current guidelines.

questions.question_text: All of the following are indications for intrauterine insemination except:
questions.explanation:
Indications for IUI

  • Mild-moderate male factors: Anejaculation, anorgasmia, retrograde ejaculation (Option B).

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Test Name

Description

Key Points

Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)

A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles.
  • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs.
  • Not affected by the menstrual cycle.
  • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve

Antral Follicle Count (AFC)

Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries.
  • Direct visual assessment.
  • Can vary with the cycle.
  • Baseline assessment and monitoring.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Initial screening of ovarian function.

Estradiol (E2)

Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH.

Inhibin B

Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles.
  • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle.

Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT)

Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate.
  • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10.
  • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve.
  • Used for detailed functional assessment.

questions.question_text: Match the following semen analysis terms with their correct definitions: 1. Aspermia a. Reduced sperm motility 2. Azoospermia b. Complete absence of semen 3. Asthenozoospermia c. Absence of sperm in the semen 4. Necrozoospermia d. High percentage of dead sperm in the semen

Condition

Definition

Aspermia

Complete absence of semen

Azoospermia

Absence of sperm in the semen

Asthenozoospermia

Reduced sperm motility

Necrozoospermia

Higher percentage of dead/ non-viable sperm in the semen

Hypospermia

Low semen volume (<1.4 ml)

Oligospermia

Sperm count <16 million per ml

Severe oligospermia

Sperm count <5 million per ml

Polyzoospermia

Sperm count >350 million per ml

Teratozoospermia

>70% sperms with abnormal morphology

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and dizziness with a history of amenorrhea for the past 8 weeks. On examination, she is pale, diaphoretic, and hypotensive with a blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. An ultrasound confirms a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with significant intra-abdominal bleeding. The patient is in shock and requires immediate surgical intervention. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient?

A 30-year-old woman presents with fever, offensive vaginal discharge, and lower abdominal pain following a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, she has uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows no evidence of spread beyond the uterus. What is the most likely clinical grade of her septic abortion?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Management

I

(Option A)

Localized infection in the uterus

Hospitalization, Antibiotics, Uterine evacuation post-antibiotics if indicated

II

(Option B)

The infection spreads beyond the uterus (parametrium, tubes, ovaries)

Broad-spectrum antibiotics, Analgesics, Anti-tetanus serum, Clinical monitoring, Delayed evacuation

III

(Option C)

Generalized peritonitis or shock, often from illegal abortions

Intensive antibiotics, Supportive therapy, Emergency surgery if needed

Preferred Regimen

Alternatives
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam (4.5 g IV q8h)
  • Plus vancomycin based on culture resistance patterns
  • Imipenem (500 mg IV q6h)
  • Gentamicin (5 mg/kg/day IV) + Ampicillin (2 g IV q4h) + Clindamycin (900 mg IV q8h)
  • Levofloxacin (500 mg IV daily) + Metronidazole (500 mg IV q8h)

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency room at 8 weeks of gestation with heavy vaginal bleeding accompanied by severe cramping. On examination, the cervix is found to be partially dilated and ultrasound shows the presence of products of conception. Which type of spontaneous abortion is described here?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Clinical Presentation

USG Finding

Management

Threatened Abortion

(option A)

Vaginal bleeding during the first 20 weeks of pregnancy while the embryo or fetus is still alive and the cervical os remains closed.

Vaginal bleeding: spotting to heavy flow

Symptoms: suprapubic discomfort, mild cramps, pelvic pressure

TVS: Detects viable intrauterine pregnancy.

Fetal cardiac activity (by 6-6.5 weeks), subchorionic hematoma (may be present).

Expectant management: Monitor symptoms, acetaminophen for pain relief, avoid sexual intercourse. Progesterone supplementation is not recommended.

Incomplete Abortion

(Option B)

The cervix begins to open.

Incompletely expelled products of conception.

Heavier vaginal bleeding with cramping.

TVS: Retained products of conception in the uterus, and dilated cervix.

Surgical evacuation (curettage): High success rate (95-100%). - Expectant management: Higher failure rate (~25%). Medication (Misoprostol): Induces contractions, failure rate 5-30%.

Complete Abortion

(Option C)

All products of conception are expelled from the uterus and the cervix closes.

Bleeding subsides, and cramping decreases.

TVS: Thin endometrium, no gestational sac. Serial β-hCG is helpful if uncertain.

No further intervention is usually needed.

Anti D if Rh +ve.

Missed Abortion

(Option D)

Nonviable pregnancy, products of conception retained within the uterus, closed cervix.

Disappearance of pregnancy symptoms, light brown vaginal discharge.

TVS:

  • Absence of fetal cardiac activity (CRL ≥7mm), (or)
  • MSD ≥25mm without visible embryo, (or)
  • Lack of embryo growth post-yolk sac presence (11 days) or post-initial scan (2 weeks without yolk sac)

Similar to incomplete abortion.

Inevitable Abortion of a Previable Fetus

Cervical dilation with ruptured membranes (PPROM) or significant membrane ballooning, making continuation impossible.

Abundant watery vaginal discharge increases with coughing or the Valsalva manoeuvre.

Ultrasound: Confirms PPROM with decreased amniotic fluid or visualization of fluid between amnion and chorion.

First Trimester: Leads to uterine contractions or infection, necessitating termination. Second Trimester (Previable):

  • Bleeding or Fever: Immediate uterine evacuation.
  • No Bleeding or Fever: Expectant management with close monitoring, antibiotics if needed.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of a missed period and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

questions.question_text: A 28 y/o woman presents with cramping and some vaginal bleeding. She is estimated to be at 8 weeks gestation based on her last menstrual period. Ultrasound confirms an intrauterine pregnancy with no fetal cardiac activity and closed cervix. Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate?

options.A: Mifepristone 200 mg orally as a single dose.
options.B: Mifepristone 200 mg orally followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally 24 hours later.
options.C: Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hours.

questions.explanation:
Trimester

Regimen

Indication

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Medical abortion; Miscarriage.

Best method with a high success rate.
 

Mifepristone 200 mg orally alone is not effective in MTP. (Option A)

Miscarriage

Not effective

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.
 

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Used when Mifepristone is not available.
 

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

(Option C)

MTP

Less commonly used.
 

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline

(Option D)

MTP

Longer induction duration, hence, rarely used.

questions.question_text: A 28 y/o woman presents to a government-approved clinic seeking a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). She is 8 weeks pregnant and is unmarried. She has no significant medical history and physical examination is within normal limits. According to the MTP Act, what is the most appropriate method of abortion for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks) (Option A)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation (Option B)

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E) (Option C)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy (Option D)

questions.question_text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of pelvic pressure and a sensation of vaginal fullness. She denies any contractions, bleeding, or fluid leakage. Her history is significant for two previous second-trimester losses. On physical examination, her cervix appears shortened and external os is patulous. Which of the following tests helps in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics:
  • Painless dilation of the cervix in the 2nd trimester.
  • Characterized by spontaneous, painless dilation of the cervix followed by expulsion of products of conception.

Risk factors:
  • Past history of cervical surgeries such as LEEP, and conization.
  • Cervical trauma (during labour or instrumental delivery).
  • Congenital abnormality.

Diagnosis:

History of pregnancy loss in 2nd trimester:

  • TVUS- investigation of choice (Option C).
  • Normal shape and length of the cervix- T shaped and 3-4 cm.
  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm with one 2nd trimester painless abortion, then diagnosed as cervical insufficiency.

Non-pregnant women:

If the Hegar no. 8 dilator can be passed through the internal os without any resistance.

Management:

Progesterone and cervical cerclage placement.

questions.question_text: A 32 y/o woman presents to her gynaecologist with a history of three consecutive first-trimester miscarriages. She and her partner are both healthy and have no significant medical history. Which of the following investigations should be done?
questions.explanation:

Cause

questions.question_text: A 28 year old woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding and severe lower abdominal pain at 14 weeks gestation. She reports passing large clots and tissue. Per speculum examination reveals an open cervix with active bleeding and presence of fetal tissue in the vagina coming out of the os. What is the most likely type of spontaneous abortion?
questions.explanation:
1)Threatened Abortion

(Option A)

Defined as bleeding through a closed cervical os in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy and with a live embryo or fetus. In this type, miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible.

2) Inevitable Abortion

(Option B)

 Either rupture of placental membranes or marked ballooning of membranes into the vagina may lead to inevitable abortion. In this type of abortion, the changes have progressed to a state where the continuation of pregnancy is impossible. There is dilated internal os and the presence of products of conception.

3) Complete Abortion

When the products of conception are expelled en masse, it is called a complete miscarriage. In complete abortion, bleeding and the internal cervical os subsequently closes over the next hour or so.

4) Missed Abortion

(Option D)

This describes dead products of conception that have been retained for days or weeks within the uterus with a closed cervical os.

5) Incomplete Abortion

(Option C)

When the entire products of conception are not expelled, instead a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity, it is called incomplete abortion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

options.A: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L
options.C: Gestation sac size less than 4 cm
options.D: No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old woman’s transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 5 cm ectopic pregnancy located in the ampulla of the right fallopian tube. The initial serum beta hCG level was 3500 IU/L and has remained stable despite receiving three doses of methotrexate. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of amenorrhea for 7 weeks. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. The physician suspects an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and advises USG evaluation with beta hCG assay. Which of the following findings is not typically seen for diagnosing an unruptured ectopic pregnancy?

options.A: Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
options.B: Failure to double the value of β-hCG by 48 hours along with an empty uterus
options.C: Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary
options.D: Presence of ring-of-fire pattern on Colour Doppler TVS

questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign). (Option C)
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler. (Option D)
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours (Option B)
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding and a positive pregnancy test. Her serum β-hCG level is 180,000 mIU/mL. Which of the following benign gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) is most likely in this patient?

questions.question_text: A 34 y/o woman presents with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels following a molar pregnancy. Imaging studies reveal no evidence of metastases. What is the most appropriate initial chemotherapy regimen for her condition?

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Her condition is complicated by metastasis to the lungs, but no other distant sites are involved. According to the FIGO staging system, what is the appropriate stage for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Defining Criteria

Stage I

GTN is confined to the uterus. (Option A)

Stage II

GTN extends to the genital structures (e.g., vagina or pelvis) but does not spread to the lungs or other distant sites. (Option B)

Stage III

GTN has metastasized to the lungs, with or without involvement of genital structures.

Stage IV

GTN has metastasized to distant sites other than the lungs (e.g., liver, brain). (Option D)

questions.question_text: A 25 y/o woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, an enlarged uterus, and elevated beta-hCG levels, suggesting molar pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. An Ultrasound finding of the ovaries is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the tumor marker associated with choriocarcinoma?

Feature

Partial Mole

Complete Mole

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing Gestational Trophoblastic Disease?

A 30 Y/o pregnant woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents for routine follow-up and has no complaints. Laboratory investigations: Hb 6.2 g/dL MCV 68 fL MCH 21 pg Which of the following iron therapy is recommended for the patient?
questions.explanation:
Hb

≤11 g/dL

MCV

<80 fL

MCH

<27 pg

Ferritin

<12 microgram/dL

Serum hepcidin

Decreased

Antepartum period

  • Hb < 4 g/dL with/without signs and symptoms
  • Hb 5-7 g/dL with signs of impending heart failure or hemodynamic instability

>36 weeks of gestation
  • Hb <7 g/dL even with no symptoms (Option D ruled out)

questions.question_text: A 32 Y/o woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of persistent headaches and visual disturbances. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and she has 2+ proteinuria on a urine dipstick test. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gestational HTN (Option A ruled out)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation at 2 separate occasions 6 hrs apart in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria or end organ damage

Chronic HTN (Option B ruled out)
  • Pre-existing HTN presenting < 20 weeks of gestation

Acute on chronic HTN
  • Chronic HTN patient with superimposed gestational HTN
  • New onset proteinuria after 20 weeks gestation

Preeclampsia (Option C)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation associated with:
  • Proteinuria: ≥300 mg/24 h of urine or 1+ on urine dipstick
  • Urine protein: Creatinine >0.3

Or

  • End organ damage: Platelets <1,00,000/microL; Creatinine >1.1 mg/dL; doubling of serum transaminase level; headache, visual disturbances

Eclampsia (Option D ruled out)
  • Preeclampsia + generalized tonic-clonic seizures

Delta HTN
  • Sudden rise in mean arterial pressure in pregnant women, even though being at normal levels

questions.question_text: A 32 Y/o pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and headaches. Blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. Laboratory results reveal hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and a low platelet count. Which of the following is the definitive management for a patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
HELLP Syndrome:

Rare complication of Preeclampsia, which usually occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy

Features:

  • H- Hemolysis
  • EL- Elevated Liver enzymes
  • LP- Low Platelets

Risk factors:

  • HELLP in prior pregnancy, age >35, multiparous, history of diabetes, kidney disease

Symptoms:

  • RUQ pain, headache, blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, edema

Maternal complications:

  • Blood clotting problems, DIC
  • Kidney failure
  • Liver failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia

Fetal complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Growth restriction
  • Respiratory distress

Treatment:

  • Majority of patients develop eclampsia- MgSO4 to prevent seizures (Option C)
  • Antihypertensives to control BP (Option B)
  • If <34 weeks, Corticosteroids for lung maturity (Option D)
  • Definitive treatment: Termination of pregnancy (Option A)

Differential diagnosis: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks gestation. She conceived spontaneously and her ultrasound reveals a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. She has no significant past medical history and her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

options.A: Schedule routine antenatal visits every 4 weeks until 28 weeks, then every 2 weeks until 36 weeks, and weekly thereafter.
options.B: Initiate aspirin 81 mg daily and refer to a maternal-fetal medicine specialist for further management.
options.C: Perform a cerclage at 12 weeks to prevent preterm labor.
options.D: Advise bed rest starting from the second trimester to reduce the risk of preterm birth.

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is receiving magnesium sulfate for the management of severe preeclampsia. After several hours of infusion, she exhibits diminished patellar reflexes and mild respiratory depression. Her serum magnesium level is found to be 12 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5-9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents for her 20-week anatomy scan. The ultrasound reveals multiple thin, sheet-like structures floating in the amniotic fluid. The fetus appears to have constriction rings around the left arm and right leg, and the left hand seems to be malformed. Based on the ultrasound findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 34 weeks gestation presents with a fundal height of 40 cm. Ultrasound confirms polyhydramnios with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 30 cm. The patient reports feeling short of breath and uncomfortable. Which of the following is NOT a common complication in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Maternal

Fetal
  • During Pregnancy
    • Increased incidence of pre-eclampsia
    • Malpresentation and floating head
    • Premature rupture of membranes
    • Preterm labour (spontaneous or induced) (Option A)
    • Accidental haemorrhage
 
  • During Labor
    • Early rupture of membranes
    • Cord prolapse (Option C)
    • Uterine inertia
    • Increased operative delivery due to malpresentation
    • Retained placenta, postpartum haemorrhage, and shock (due to uterine atony)
 
  • During Puerperium
    • Subinvolution
    • Increased puerperal morbidity (due to infection, operative interference, and blood loss).
    • PPH- Overdistended uterus may not contract well after delivery (Option D)
  • Increased perinatal mortality (about 50%).
  • Prematurity and congenital abnormality (40%).
  • Cord prolapse.
  • Effects of Increased Operative Delivery.

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old primigravida, at 28 weeks of gestation, has been diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) after routine screening. She has a family history of type 2 diabetes and a BMI of 30. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

questions.question_text: A 32 Y/o pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, palpitations, and swelling in B/L ankles. On physical examination, persistent jugular venous distension, a diastolic murmur, and bilateral pitting edema are present. Which of the following is most concerning for heart disease in this patient?

questions.explanation:
Indicators of heart disease in pregnancy:

Symptoms

Progressive Dyspnea

Orthopnea

Nocturnal cough

Syncope

Chest pain

Signs

Cyanosis

Clubbing

Jugular venous distension

Systolic murmur grade>= 3/6

Diastolic murmur

S4 +ve heart sound

Cardiomegaly

Persistent tachycardia

Findings seen in normal pregnancy

  • Shortness of breath
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue (Option B)
  • Bilateral pitting edema (Option C)
  • Loud S1 and S3 +ve
  • End systolic murmur < garde 3/6

questions.question_text: A 28 year old woman, G2 P1 L1 at 38 weeks gestation is seen in early labor. She has a history of cesarean section done 3 years ago for breech presentation. The obstetrician decides on a cesarean section. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a cesarean section in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Maternal Indications for Cesarean Delivery
  • Prior Cesarean Delivery: most common
  • Abnormal Placentation (Option A): Placenta previa and placenta accreta
  • Prior Classical Hysterotomy
  • Prior Uterine Incision Extension
  • Uterine Incision Dehiscence (Option B)
  • Prior Full-Thickness Myomectomy
  • Genital Tract Obstructive Mass
  • Invasive Cervical Cancer
  • Prior Trachelectomy
  • Permanent Cerclage
  • Prior Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery
  • Prior Significant Perineal Trauma
  • Pelvic Deformity
  • HSV or HIV Infection
  • Cardiac or Pulmonary Disease.
  • Cerebral Aneurysm or Arteriovenous Malformation: Increase the risk of a stroke
  • Pathology Requiring Concurrent Intraabdominal Surgery
  • Perimortem Cesarean Delivery

Selection criteria for TOLAC

Contraindications for TOLAC

One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar

Previous classical or inverted T shaped uterine incision

Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section

Previous more than two lower segment cesarean section

Pelvis adequate for fetus

Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD

Continued labor monitoring possible

Presence of other complications in pregnancy: obstetric ( malpresentation , pre-eclampsia , placenta previa) or medical

Availability of resources (anesthesia , blood transfusion) for emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of decision

Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC

Informed consent of the women

History of prior uterine rupture

questions.question_text: Which among the following statements on the first stage of labour is false?

options.C: The upper uterine segment contracts and the lower uterine segment dilates.
options.D: During contraction, maternal heart rate and systolic blood pressure increase.

questions.explanation:
Aspect of First Stage of Labour

Description

Onset
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions followed by the expulsion of blood-stained mucous(show) from the vagina.

Uterine Contractions
  • Painful, involuntary, and gradual increase in frequency and intensity.
  • Intervals between contractions shorten from approximately 10 minutes to as little as 1 minute or less.

Cervical Changes
  • Effacement (shortening and thinning of the cervix) and dilation (opening of the cervix up to 10 cm) occur progressively during labour.Effacement precedes dilation.

Distinct Uterine Segments
  • The upper segment contracts firmly.
  • The lower segment remains softer and passive to facilitate fetal descent.

Maternal Physiological Changes
  • Increased heart rate and systolic blood pressure during contractions; relaxation between contractions essential for uteroplacental blood flow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an event in the second stage of labor?

options.D: Expulsion of blood-stained mucous per vagina(show)

questions.explanation:
Aspect of Second Stage of Labour

Description

Definition

  • Full dilatation of the cervix to expulsion of the fetus.

Pain and Intensity
  • Pain intensifies with contractions

Bearing Down Efforts
  • Voluntary expulsive efforts due to vaginal stretching by the presenting part (head).
  • Efforts should coincide with uterine contractions.
  • Sustained pushing beyond contractions is discouraged.

Membrane Status
  • Membranes may rupture with a gush of amniotic fluid either before or during the descent of the fetus.
  • Rarely, the baby may be born in the caul (intact membranes).

Descent of the Fetus
  • Head rotation also occurs.

Vulva

  • 'Crowning' of the head occurs when the widest part of the head stretches the vulval outlet.

questions.question_text: Given below is the instrument used in a procedure done in the second stage of labor. What is the most commonly performed type of this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.
  • It may not be suitable for all cases, depending on perineal anatomy.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Reduced risk of injury to the anal sphincter.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

Lateral/
Transverse
  • Potential for reducing the risk of severe perineal tears compared to midline.
  • Less disruption to perineal body alignment.
  • May be quicker to perform in some cases.
  • Higher risk of complications such as Bartholin's duct injury.
  • Increased likelihood of uneven wound healing.
  • Not preferred due to the potential for structural damage and poor cosmetic outcomes.

T-shaped
  • Potential for minimising anal sphincter injury.
  • May provide better vaginal opening in complex deliveries.
  • Less risk of perineal tear extension.
  • Complex to perform.
  • Likely to cause puckering and imperfect wound closure.
  • Not widely recommended due to the potential for postoperative complications and difficult repair.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after a vaginal delivery with complaints of severe perineal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Upon examination, a third-degree perineal tear is diagnosed. What is the not done as next step in management?
questions.explanation:
1

Positioning

Lithotomy position, clean the area.

2

Anaesthesia

Local infiltration with lignocaine, pudendal block, or regional/general anaesthesia.

3

Suturing steps
  1. Start with rectal and anal mucosa using No. 3-0 vicryl or PDS, interrupted sutures with knots inside.
  2. Suture rectal muscles and pararectal fascia with interrupted sutures using the same material.
  3. Reconstruct sphincter ani externus (EAS) with figure-of-eight stitch, support with additional interrupted sutures.
  4. Repair perineal muscles with interrupted No. 0 PDS or similar, and bury knots under superficial muscles.
  5. Close the vaginal wall and perineal skin with interrupted sutures.

4

Suture materials
  • External anal sphincter: PDS or vicryl.
  • Internal anal sphincter: Finer sutures like 3-0 PDS.

5

After care
  • Similar to post-episiotomy care.
  • Specific care for complete tear repairs:
    • Low-residue diet post-repair.
    • Lactulose to soften stools.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Pelvic floor exercises.
    • Follow-up at 6-12 weeks postpartum.
    • Further consultations for persistent incontinence.

6

Future Pregnancies
  • Institutional Delivery: Recommended for all women post-repair.
  • Vaginal Delivery: May be considered with or without an episiotomy.
  • Elective Caesarean: Recommended for women with symptoms or abnormal findings on endoanal ultrasound or anorectal manometry.

questions.explanation:

Route

Uses

Contraindications

Ergometrine (0.25 mg)

IM

600 mcg Rectally, orally, sublingually
  • Ripening of cervix.

Carbetocin (analogue of oxytocin)

100 mcg i.v over 1 min
  • AMTSL

  • Longer half-life

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not an indication of early cord clamping?

A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with her second child at 38 weeks, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit due to decreased fetal movements. A cardiotocography (CTG) is performed, revealing a baseline fetal heart rate of 130 beats per minute with decelerations. These decelerations vary in shape, timing, and duration, often occurring independently of contractions and sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes. Based on the CTG findings described, what is the most likely underlying cause?
Which perinatal outcome is more common in breech presentations than cephalic presentations, regardless of mode of delivery?
questions.explanation:
Category

Complications

Maternal
  • Increased risk of operative delivery (cesarean section or assisted vaginal delivery).
  • Increased risk of perineal trauma.
  • Prolonged labour.
  • Postpartum haemorrhage.
  • Pain and discomfort
  • Infection

Fetal
  • Umbilical cord prolapse.
  • Birth trauma, including head injuries (due to increased risk of head entrapment in vaginal delivery).
  • Hypoxic-ischemic injury due to cord compression or prolonged delivery.
  • Increased risk of birth defects or anomalies.

During Delivery
  • Shoulder dystocia (especially in breech extraction during vaginal delivery).
  • Delayed delivery of the aftercoming head (leading to potential birth asphyxia).
  • Increased risk of brachial plexus injuries.
  • Increased risk of fetal fractures (such as clavicle fractures).
  • Difficulty delivering the placenta (due to abnormal presentation).

questions.question_text: A 28 year old multiparous woman at 39 weeks gestation arrives at the labour and delivery unit in active labour. She is confirmed to have a frank breech presentation. Which of the following is NOT a prerequisite for proceeding with assisted breech extraction?

questions.question_text: Match the following images of forceps with their names. 1. a. Simpson forceps 2. b. Piper forceps 3. c. Wrigley's forceps 4.​​​​​​​ d. Kielland forceps
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.question_text: Which statement regarding the Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP) is false?

options.A: ICP is characterised by pruritus and pale stools

questions.explanation:
Risk Factors
  • Personal or family history of ICP
  • Multiple gestations
  • Hepatitis C infection

Clinical Features
  • Pruritus, especially on the palms and soles
  • Jaundice (in some cases)

  • Pale stools
  • Fatigue

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, and extreme fatigue. On physical examination, she appears icteric, and her liver is mildly tender but not enlarged. Laboratory tests reveal AST & ALT >200 IU/L, Total Bilirubin 5.5 mg/dL, PT 18 seconds, Serum Creatinine 2.5mg/dl, and Blood Glucose 55 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

A rare, life-threatening liver disorder that occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy, characterised by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes.

Risk Factors
  • First pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Male fetus
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Maternal obesity
  • Prior history of AFLP

Clinical Features
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice
  • Malaise and fatigue
  • Anorexia
  • Polydipsia and polyuria
  • Ascites (rare)

Complications
  • Liver failure
  • Renal failure
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Encephalopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery of the baby (definitive treatment)
  • Supportive care for the mother: IV fluids, glucose infusion, and blood products for coagulopathy.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, delivered a healthy baby girl via normal vaginal delivery. She is now 2 weeks postpartum and presents for a follow-up visit. Midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was recorded as February 15, 2024. She reports regular 28-day menstrual cycles. What is her estimated delivery date (EDD)?

Placental hormones

Extra placental sites of secretion

Functions

Human chorionic gonadotropin

(Option B)

(Option D)

(Option A)

questions.question_text: Which cell type in the placenta is primarily responsible for producing human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and human placental lactogen (hPL)?
During fetal development, which of the following accurately represents the time period of development of the tertiary villus?
At approximately what gestational age is the development of the placenta generally completed?
questions.explanation:
Day 11-13
  • Placental development begins with the blastocyst implanting into the uterine wall by day 11, leading to lacunar spaces and trabeculae forming by day 13.
  • Stem villi develop from trabeculae, establishing connections between the chorionic and basal plates.

Day 21
  • Villi develop arterio-capillary-venous systems that connect with the embryonic circulation via the body stalk.

3-4 weeks
  • Lacunar spaces merge to form intervillous spaces, which fill with maternal blood.

Week 6
  • The decidua capsularis begins to thin, while the chorion frondosum and decidua basalis undergo robust growth, culminating in the formation of the placenta by week 12.

questions.question_text: All of the following are normal cardiovascular changes during pregnancy EXCEPT:

options.A: Systolic flow murmur over the tricuspid area
options.C: Fixed split of second heart sound (S2)
options.D: Systolic flow murmur over pulmonary area

questions.explanation:
Category

Change

Description

Clinical Implication

Hemodynamics

↑ Cardiac Output

Increases by 40–50% due to ↑ stroke volume and ↑ heart rate

Ensures adequate perfusion to uterus, placenta, and maternal organs

↑ Heart Rate

Rises by 15–30% above baseline

Compensatory response to increased circulatory demands

↓ Systemic Vascular Resistance

Falls by 25–40% from vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide, prostaglandins)

Causes drop in BP during early pregnancy

↓ Blood Pressure (initially)

Falls in 1st and 2nd trimesters, returns to baseline by term

Due to decreased SVR; important for monitoring preeclampsia

↑ Blood Volume (especially plasma)

Expands significantly, elevating preload

Supports fetal circulation; may cause flow murmurs

Cardiac Structure

↑ LV Size and Remodeling

LV mass ↑ ~30–35% near term; ↑ chamber dimensions without EF or septal changes

Normal remodeling process in pregnancy 

Auscultatory Changes

Heart Sounds

• Exaggerated splitting and louder S1

• No change in aortic/pulmonary S2

• Loud S3 

All are normal findings on auscultation during pregnancy

Murmurs

• Common: soft systolic ejection murmurs

• Occasional: soft diastolic or continuous (mammary) murmurs

Typically benign; must differentiate from pathological murmurs 

Positional Effects

Postural Changes

Supine hypotension from IVC compression in late pregnancy

May cause dizziness/syncope; alleviated by left lateral positioning

questions.question_text: A 28 y/o primigravida, currently in her third trimester, presents to the clinic complaining of dizziness and shortness of breath, especially when lying on her back. She feels better when she shifts to her left side. What is the condition likely due to?

Hormone

Function

Estrogen (Option B)

Progesterone (Option A)

Development of the alveoli in the breasts
Prolactin (Option C)

Oxytocin (Option D)
  • Milk ejection reflex or let-down reflex during breastfeeding.
  • It causes the myoepithelial cells to contract and expel milk from the alveoli into the ducts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following women should seek alternative contraception methods due to absolute contraindications for combined oral contraceptive pills?

options.B: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines without aura
options.C: A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer
options.D: A 25-year-old woman with well-managed type1 diabetes

questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications of Combined Oral Contraceptives Pills (COCs)

Condition

Remarks

Pregnancy
  • COCs are strictly prohibited during pregnancy.

Circulatory Diseases (Past or Present)
  • Women who have a history of arterial or venous thrombosis, severe hypertension, stroke, or heart disease (valvular or ischemic) should avoid combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs).
  • The estrogen component in COCs can raise the risk of deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • This is because estrogen stimulates the liver to produce fibrinogen and clotting factors, which can contribute to clot formation.

Liver Diseases
  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) should not be used by women with active liver disease, jaundice, liver adenoma, or liver carcinoma.
  • The estrogen in COCs can increase the synthesis of hepatic angiotensinogen, which may contribute to hypertension.

Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding
  • COC use is not recommended for women with undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding.

Breast Cancer (Current or Past)
  • Women with known or suspected breast cancer should not use COCs.

Major Surgery or Prolonged Immobilisation
  • COCs are contraindicated in women who have recently undergone major surgery or experienced prolonged immobilization due to the increased risk of postoperative VTE.

Estrogen-Dependent Neoplasms
  • Women with known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasms should avoid using COCs.

Smoking and Age
  • COCs are not recommended for women older than 35 who smoke.

Diabetes with Vascular Complications
  • Women with diabetes and vascular complications should not use COCs.

Migraines with Focal Neurologic Symptoms
  • COCs should be avoided by women experiencing migraines with focal neurological symptoms.

questions.question_text: A 19 y/o female presents with primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and pubic hair growth. On physical examination, her external genitalia are normal but the vaginal canal is shorter than usual. A USG reveals the absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, but the ovaries are present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Complete Vaginal Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)

Definition
  • Developmental defects of the Müllerian ducts result in the absence of structures derived from them, namely the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.
  • Normal ovaries and external genitalia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Examination: Shallow vaginal pouch measuring 1–2 cm in length.
  • Phenotypic Sex: Female, with normal breast development, body proportions, hair distribution, and external genitalia.
  • Genetic Sex: Female (46, XX karyotype).
  • Associated with skeletal and spine abnormalities (20%-30%) and urological abnormalities like malrotation of kidneys, ectopic kidneys (e.g., horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney).

Diagnosis
  • Imaging: Pelvic and abdominal ultrasound, 3D ultrasound, and MRI.
  • Karyotyping. 

Differential Diagnoses
  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) (Option A): 
    • Karyotype is 46 XY, and testosterone levels are typically in the male range.
    • Normal female external genitalia & breast development.
    • Primary amenorrhea.
    • Lack of uterus or undescended testes (abdomen or inguinal canal).
    • Lack of axillary and pubic hair.
  • Imperforate hymen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum.

Treatment
  • Nonsurgical methods: Frank's method of dilation.
  • Surgical vaginoplasty.

What is the recommended management for an individual with Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) who is reared as a female?

options.B: Early gonadectomy and long-term estrogen replacement therapy

questions.explanation:
Treatment of Testicular Feminization Syndrome

Female Gender Assignment

(Reared as a girl)

Male Gender Assignment

(Conversion as a male)
  • Gonadectomy: Testes (which are ectopic and present in the abdomen or inguinal canal) are typically removed due to the high risk of gonadal malignancy (20-30% risk), specifically gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma (Option B).
 
  • Timing: Gonadectomy is usually performed at the start of puberty.
 
  • Estrogen Replacement Therapy: After gonadectomy, long-term estrogen therapy is prescribed to induce and maintain secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development) and for the health of the vaginal epithelium (Option B).
 
  • Vaginoplasty: Reconstruction of the vagina is considered after completion of growth (around 16-18 years of age) to allow for normal sexual function.
  • Surgical and Medical Management: The decision to transition to male involves considerations such as the size of the phallus and the feasibility of constructing a penile urethra (Option C).
 
  • Testosterone Therapy: Testosterone is administered to induce virilization and promote the development of male secondary sexual characteristics, including enlargement of the phallus. (Option A)
 
  • Timing: Testosterone therapy may begin before puberty to maximize its effects on phallic growth, especially in cases of 5-alpha reductase deficiency.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles and is not sexually active. Which hormone would you expect to be deficient or irregular in her case, leading to anovulation?
questions.explanation:
Hormone

Role in Menstrual Cycle

Luteinizing Hormone (LH) (Option D)
  • Triggers ovulation approximately 12-36 hours after surge.
  • Regulated by sex hormone feedback mechanisms.

Estrogen (Option A)
  • Promotes growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during follicular phase.
  • Thickens endometrium for implantation.

Progesterone (Option B)

It supports the luteal phase post-ovulation and prepares the uterus for potential implantation but does not initiate ovulation.

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) (Option C)
  • Stimulates recruitment and initial growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Induces estrogen (estradiol) production to support follicular development.

Adult type hair covering the mons only (Median age: 12 years)

Stage V

Adult hair with an inverse triangle distribution (female escutcheon) covering the medial thighs (Median age: 13.7 years)

questions.question_text: A 7-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Laboratory findings reveal elevated gonadotropin levels. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Central (True precocious puberty)

Peripheral precocious puberty
  • Premature activation of the HPO axis
  • Elevated LH (diagnostic)
  • Elevated FSH (diagnostic)
  • Elevated estrogen
  • Due to an increase in estrogen, puberty is always isosexual
  • Due to the exogenous production of estrogen
  • Isolated elevated estrogen and elevated androgen.
  • Negative feedback on LH and FSH
  • Due to:
    • Elevated estrogen: Isosexual
    • Elevated androgen: Heterosexual

Causes:

  • 90% idiopathic
  • 10% brain tumor (hamartoma of tuber cinerum)

Always do an MRI scan

Causes:

  • Elevated estrogen
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Hypothyroidism (Alpha subunit similar to LH and FSH).
    • McCune Albright syndrome
  • Elevated androgen
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (androgen-secreting tumor of ovary)
    • CAH (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia)

questions.question_text: A 6-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Which among the following investigations can differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty?

A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of irregular menstrual periods for the past year, along with occasional hot flashes and night sweats but denies any recent pregnancies or use of hormonal contraceptives. Hormonal testing reveals elevated serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and low estradiol levels. Which of the following is false in this condition?

options.A: Ovarian biopsy is essential to the diagnosis
options.C: Due to an accelerated rate of germ cell depletion
options.D: Due to the failure of germ cell migration in intrauterine life
